EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1.0    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



     The Monument Chemical facility in Brandenburg, Kentucky (formerly Arch Chemicals, Inc.) is committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and responsible manner.  As a company, we are committed to excellence in health, safety, security, and environmental protection.  Monument Chemical Kentucky, LLC has been certified by the Society of Chemical Manufacturers and Affiliates (SOCMA) to have been accessed and found to be in conformance with the requirements established by the CHEMSTEWARDS® Management System.   Monument operates under the philosophy that all accidents are preventable all of the time.  A combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs are used to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as to protect the environment.    



The following sections provide a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities in practice at the Brandenburg facility.  Also attached are the data elements from our risk management program that are required by EPA's RMP rule.



2.0    Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



    The Monument Chemical Kentucky, LLC Brandenburg facility is a 220-acre site located east of Brandenburg, Kentucky.  The facility is divided into 8 operating units including Propylene Glycol/Glycol Ethers, Polychemicals, Polymer Polyol, Microelectronics, Pilot Plant, Utilities, Waste Water Treatment, and Warehouse/Shipping.  The primary products manufactured at the facility include polyether polyols, propylene glycols,  glycol ethers, and microelectronics chemicals.  

In our processes, we use the following toxic chemicals that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:

*Ethylene Oxide - purchased and used in the production of polyether polyols and ethylene glyco

l ethers; maximum quantity handled/stored at the facility is 970,000 pounds.

*Propylene Oxide - purchased used in the production of polyether polyols, propylene glycol, and propylene glycol ethers; maximum quantity handled/stored at the facility is 7,500,000 pounds.

*Formaldehyde - purchased used in the Microelectronics Unit for the production of Novolak solutions; maximum quantity handled/stored at one location in the facility is 30,000 pounds.

*Acrylonitrile - purchased and used in the Polymer Polyol Unit to produce a styrene acrylonitrile polymer dispersion in a polyether polyol; maximum quantity handled/stored at the facility is 80,000 pounds.



*Ammonia (>20%) - produced as a byproduct in the Polymer Polyol Units and subsequently used or purchased for the Waste Water Treatment (WWT) Unit as a nutrient for activated sludge; maximum quantity handled/stored at the facility is 100,000 pounds at WWT and 50,000 pounds at Polymer Polyol.  

*Ethylenediamine - purchased and used in the Polychemicals Unit to produce various polyols; maximum quantity handled/stored at the facility is 80,000 pounds.



3.0    Key Offsite Consequence Analysis Scenarios



EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst case release scenario and alternate release scenarios for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios and our assessment of the potential off-site consequences from accidental chemical releases, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario:



Toxics:  Worst Case Release Scenario



Ethylene Oxide:  The selected worst case release scenario assumes the failure of a railcar containing up to 170,000 pounds of ethylene oxide.  The required assumption is that the entire contents of the tank are released in 10 minutes.    Using the USEPA RMP*Comp software, rural topography and stipulated meteorology of wind speed of 1.5 m/sec (3.4 mph) and F stabili

ty class, and with no mitigation measures, the ethylene oxide could travel a significant distance before dispersing enough to no longer pose a significant hazard to the public.  A release of this magnitude could potentially impact area residences and schools in Meade County as well as residences in Hardin County, Jefferson County and Harrison County, IN.  Environmental receptors within this 11 mile radius include Otter Creek State Park, the Fort Knox military base, South Harrison State Park, and Mosquito Creek Nature Conservatory.  Although unrealistic, this scenario meets the requirements of a release of the largest quantity from a vessel that has the potential for the farthest off-site impact.  Passive mitigation in the form of dikes or collection drains were not considered for this release scenario.  Although the facility also has active mitigation controls including sprinkler and deluge systems that would be utilized in a release of this type, they were not considered in the consequence analysis for this "worst case" release scenario.



Toxics:  Alternate Release Scenario



In accordance with the EPA RMP rule, more credible alternate release scenarios were also considered for each toxic chemical.  This scenario is often called the planning scenario because we use the information to develop our detailed emergency response plans.  While a number of scenarios are considered for each of the chemicals covered by the RMP, only one for each toxic chemical is presented.  All scenarios were evaluated using the USEPA RMP*Comp software and the stipulated alternate weather conditions of 3.0 m/sec (6.7 mph) wind speed and D stability class.



Formaldehyde:  The more credible alternate release scenario for formaldehyde considers a leak in a 1.5 inch line.  The line has isolation valves at each end which will be manually shut by operators required to oversee all material transfers.  Approximately 38 pounds of formaldehyde would be released over a ten-minute period.  The for

maldehyde would travel only a short distance before dispersing enough to no longer pose a significant hazard to the public.  The resulting plume would remain onsite and would not include any public receptors.



Ethylenediamine:  An evaluation of credible releases of ethylenediamine (EDA) from the facility produced no scenarios that could potentially result in an off-site impact.  The most credible alternate release scenario for EDA considers a transfer hose rupture.  Because of shutoff valves at the tank truck and the storage tank, no more than 120 pounds of EDA would be spilled.  The resulting plume would remain onsite and would not include any public receptors.



Ethylene Oxide:  The more credible alternate release scenario for ethylene oxide considers a release from a process safety valve in the Polychemical Unit area.  Approximately 370 pounds is released during a 10 minute period.  The resulting plume could travel a short distance before dispersing enough to no longer pose a significant hazard to the public. The resulting plume would remain onsite and would not include any public receptors.

 

Propylene Oxide:  The more credible alternate release scenario for propylene oxide considers a release from a process safety valve in the Polychemical Unit area.  Approximately 2,270 pounds is released to the air during a 10 minute period.  The resulting plume could travel a short distance offsite before dispersing enough to no longer pose a significant hazard to the public.  The resulting plume would remain onsite and would likely not include any public receptors.

 

Acrylonitrile:  The more credible alternate release scenario for acrylonitrile is a leak from an unloading hose from a tank truck.  An operator is always present during truck unloading and would promptly stop the unloading pump.  Approximately 830 pounds of liquid acrylonitrile would be spilled during a 10 minute period, resulting in a plume that could travel a short distance offsite before dispersing en

ough to no longer pose a significant hazard to the public.  The resulting plume would remain onsite and would not include any public receptors.







Ammonia (24% solution in water):  The more credible alternate release scenario for ammonia considers the failure of an ammonia process line due to external erosion.  Liquid ammonia is spilled to the ground and 415 pounds is released to the ground and air.  The release lasts for approximately 10 minutes and travels a short distance offsite before dispersing enough to no longer pose a significant hazard to the public.  The resulting plume would remain onsite and would not include any public receptors.



                                                                                                                                                                                                      

4.0    General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



A systematic, proactive approach is taken to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs, including:



-Employee involvement

-Process safety information

-Process hazard analysis

-Mechanical integrity

-Operating procedures

-Training

-Management of Change

-Pre-startup reviews

-Emergency  preparedness

-Incident Investigation

-Hot work permits

-Contractor safety performance

-Compliance audits







As part of our prevention efforts, we have implemented the following chemical specific prevention steps:



1.    Administratively limit the inventory for toxic chemicals handled at the facility, including ethylene oxide, propylene oxide, and acrylonitrile.  

2.    Conduct extensive in-process and effluent wastewater monitoring in excess of NPDES permit requirements for derivatives of ethylene oxide and propylene oxide.

3.    Reduced process uses and storage volumes for formaldehyde and ethylenediamine by product elimination.  Eliminate

d  the storage of hydrochloric acid and hydrazine above threshold planning quantities.

4.    Upgraded ethylene oxide storage tank mechanical integrity by replacing insulation and adding stainless steel sheathing.  Upgraded storage tank level instrumentation and added actuated shut off valves for liquid lines at each storage tank.

5.           Utilize LEL gas detection monitors at ethylene oxide unloading, pump transfer, and processing area locations.

6.      Replaced the A-11 packed tower scrubber for ethylene oxide tank storage vents and railcar unloading operations.



The individual elements of our prevention program, along with the chemical specific prevention steps, work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we do business and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.



5.0    Five-Year Accident History



Records are maintained for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  During the past five years, the Brandenburg facility has experienced no RMP chemical releases to the atmosphere which have caused injuries to plant operators.



6.0    Emergency Response Program



Monument Chemical operates under the philosophy that "all accidents are preventable all of the time."   Monument is committed to providing a safe environment for all employees, visitors and the surrounding community.  An Emergency Response Plan has been developed for the Brandenburg facility in order to provide an effective and efficient response to any type of incident.  The Emergency Response Plan addresses all federal, state and local regulatory requirements for emergency planning.  To assist us in the event of an emergency, local area emergency responders have been provided with our Emergency Response Plan.  The Meade County Fire Department is responsible for notifying t

he public of any release which has potential off-site impacts.



7.0    Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The Brandenburg facility has planned facility improvements that will help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, and the environment.  A USEPA contractor RMP Audit was conducted at the Brandenburg facility in March, 2012.  A Security Vulnerability Assessment (SVA) was completed during 2004 with the assistance of the Meade County Local Emergency Planning Council (LEPC) and the site SVA was then updated in 2016.  A variety of recommendations are being implemented as a result of our participation in this program, including:



1.    Increased operator training for emergency response activities.

2.    Continued drills to include the local fire department and LEPC.

3.    Continued capital equipment upgrades for existing facilities to prevent chemical releases.  



8.0    Certification



For all Program 3 covered processes at the Monument Chemical Kentucky, LLC facility, the undersigned certifies that to the best of my knowledge, information and belief, formed after reasonable inquiry, the information submitted in this Risk Management Plan is true, accurate and complete.
